In PNG’s cultural context, the idea of blessing Israel to receive blessings (a biblical promise from Genesis) is popular, which likely made the Jerusalem embassy a politically positive move at home. Additionally, **Israel has cultivated relationships with Pacific nations by offering development aid and technical assistance**, and PNG is a beneficiary of such outreach. Israel’s international aid agency (MASHAV) and related NGOs have provided agricultural expertise, water management training, and health projects in various Pacific states as a way to “cultivate rare votes of support” at the UN【11†L63-L71】【11†L65-L72】. While PNG’s direct aid from Israel is modest, the new embassy is expected to facilitate more Israeli involvement in PNG’s development. At the opening, Netanyahu noted the embassy would help “develop agriculture, health, water and technology projects” in PNG【25†L229-L237】 – sectors where PNG seeks investment【25†L229-L237】. Such promises suggest **economic/diplomatic incentives** are reinforcing the religious motivations. PNG’s economy (based on mining and agriculture) is relatively small, and having Israel as a partner – even if minor – diversifies its foreign relationships beyond the traditional heavyweights (Australia, China). 

Another factor is **alignment with powerful allies**. Papua New Guinea has close ties with Australia and the United States. The U.S. and Australia have historically encouraged Pacific microstates to side with Western positions at the UN. For PNG, backing Israel (a key U.S. ally) helps maintain goodwill with Washington. Indeed, PNG’s pro-Israel tilt grew more pronounced in the late 2010s when the U.S. under President Trump prioritized isolating anti-Israel initiatives. In 2018, PNG abstained on a UN vote condemning the U.S. embassy move to Jerusalem – a stance welcomed by Israel. More recently, **regional dynamics** come into play: PNG’s neighbors like Fiji and Tonga have also shown support for Israel, creating a regional bloc of pro-Israel Pacific votes. There is a sense of shared identity among these Pacific Christian-majority nations standing with Israel even as “other western allies have grown frustrated” with Israel’s policies【10†L171-L179】【10†L173-L181】. However, this support has occasionally sparked *domestic* debates. In PNG, some civil society groups have questioned why their government sides with Israel despite humanitarian concerns in Palestine. But these voices remain relatively small. A Pacific analyst noted that supporting Israel is *“politically convenient for [Pacific] governments because it is a majority view”* in their societies【10†L237-L245】【10†L249-L257】. That holds true in Papua New Guinea, where opposition to the pro-Israel stance is limited to small activist circles, while the mainstream public and political class remain supportive. 

In terms of **bilateral relations**, PNG’s direct engagement with Israel ramped up notably after 2020. High-level visits have occurred (e.g. PNG’s Foreign Minister visited Israel in 2020, and PM Marape planted a tree in Jerusalem in 2023). Israel does not receive much trade from PNG – bilateral trade was only about **$1 million per year** as of 2023【25†L229-L237】 – but both sides hope to increase this. PNG, for instance, can benefit from Israeli agricultural technology to improve its crop yields and food security. Militarily, there’s little direct cooperation (PNG has a small defense force), but police and security training exchanges have been discussed, especially as Israel has expertise in counter-terrorism that PNG values for domestic security. There is also a **religious tourism connection**: many affluent Papua New Guineans travel to Israel on Christian pilgrimage tours, which the PNG government has informally encouraged as part of cultural links. 

**Notable turning points** in PNG–Israel relations include the *2017 decision* to start publicly supporting Israel on contentious issues, the *2018 embassy announcement* (initially delayed) and finally the *2023 embassy opening*. Each of these marked a step up in commitment. There haven’t been serious deviations from support; however, one potential risk is domestic backlash if Pacific solidarity with Palestinians grows. The Guardian reported that in some Pacific nations, “pockets of resistance are beginning to build” among younger citizens who question unwavering support of Israel amid the Gaza war【10†L177-L185】【10†L179-L187】. In PNG, any such opposition has yet to significantly alter policy. For now, Papua New Guinea remains one of the few countries willing to consistently vote with Israel at the UN – even against overwhelming global opinion – and to take bold diplomatic steps like recognizing Jerusalem. As Marape said candidly, many countries avoid this out of caution, but PNG’s leadership views it as a matter of principle and faith【25†L213-L221】. In summary, **Papua New Guinea’s strong support for Israel** since 2000 (especially in the last decade) is rooted in religious solidarity, bolstered by friendly ties and aid from Israel, and facilitated by the geopolitical strategy of aligning with Western partners. The opening of PNG’s Jerusalem embassy in 2023 stands as a concrete testament to this support, one that Israel has warmly welcomed as it seeks out loyal allies even “under a microscope”【25†L223-L227】 in far-flung corners of the world.  

## Federated States of Micronesia  
The **Federated States of Micronesia (FSM)** – a small Pacific Island nation – has been one of Israel’s most consistent supporters since 2000, often voting with Israel (and the United States) *even when almost no one else does*. Micronesia’s population is only about 115,000 and it has no Jewish community, yet at the United Nations its record of backing Israel is remarkable. According to UN voting analyses, **Micronesia has not cast a single vote against Israel in at least the past decade**, making it an even more reliable supporter than the U.S.【10†L189-L197】【10†L191-L199】. In many General Assembly votes – from condemning Israeli settlements to urging Gaza ceasefires – Micronesia is among the tiny handful of “No” votes alongside Israel. For example, in the 2012 UN vote on Palestinian observer status, Micronesia joined Israel, the U.S., and a few others in voting *No*【5†L29-L37】【5†L39-L43】. Again in 2025, when 142 countries voted to reaffirm a two-state solution and condemn violence, Micronesia was one of only 10 voting *against*【8†L239-L244】. This pattern dates back to the 1990s and has continued unabated. In June 2025, a UN resolution calling for an immediate Gaza ceasefire saw **Micronesia and six other Pacific states** vote No, against 149 Yes votes【10†L183-L191】【10†L185-L193】. Such loyalty has at times made Micronesia famous in Israel; Israeli officials frequently express gratitude for Micronesia’s “yes” when virtually everyone else says “no.” 

The reasons for FSM’s support are multi-layered. A critical factor is **Micronesia’s unique relationship with the United States**. The Federated States of Micronesia (along with neighboring Palau and the Marshall Islands) is in a “Compact of Free Association” with the U.S. – essentially a treaty that makes these countries quasi-allies of Washington. Under this Compact, the U.S. provides financial aid and defense guarantees, and in exchange Micronesia consults closely with the U.S. on foreign policy and often votes with it in the UN【11†L63-L71】. In practice, Micronesia’s UN votes have mirrored U.S. positions approximately 95% of the time. Since the U.S. is staunchly pro-Israel, Micronesia has followed suit as a matter of alliance solidarity. As one analysis put it, *“those first three [Pacific] nations are in free association with the U.S. – they receive financial assistance in exchange for voting with the U.S.”*【11†L63-L71】. This **strategic calculus** ensures that FSM supports Israel on issues where the U.S. does. Indeed, from Micronesia’s perspective, backing Israel ingratiates them with their most important ally, America.  

Beyond U.S. influence, **Micronesia has developed a direct friendship with Israel** as well. Israel recognized and supported Micronesia when it became independent and joined the UN in 1990. Micronesian officials often mention that Israel was one of the earliest backers of Micronesia’s UN membership and nation-building, which “helped cement the relationship”【6†L173-L180】【6†L169-L177】. Over the years, Israel has provided Micronesia with technical aid and development assistance disproportionate to the country’s tiny size. Through its foreign aid agency **Mashav**, Israel has sponsored Micronesian students for agricultural training in Israel, sent experts to help with health and farming, and donated equipment for local needs【11†L67-L75】【11†L75-L83】. In the 2010s, Israeli NGOs (like Tag International Development) also engaged in Micronesia and other Pacific states to improve water access and healthcare【11†L72-L80】【11†L79-L87】. The underlying aim, as Israeli officials candidly admit, is partly to **“garner support for Israel in international forums”** while also doing good【11†L75-L83】. And it has paid off: Micronesia’s leaders feel a sense of loyalty for Israel’s attention. Former Micronesian President Emanuel Mori captured this sentiment, comparing Micronesia and Israel as two small states surviving against odds. *“Israel is a minority in the Middle East and struggling to survive… We are also out there [alone]. We have no enemies, only natural ones… Being surrounded by not-friendly neighbors, we kind of pity them,”* Mori said, expressing empathy for Israel’s predicament【6†L169-L177】【6†L171-L178】. He also noted how Israel’s early diplomatic support created a lasting bond【6†L173-L180】. Such statements reveal an **ideological affinity**: Micronesians see their own struggles with isolation and nature as analogous to Israel’s struggle for survival, fostering a kinship despite vast geographical distance. 

**Religious and cultural ties** further reinforce FSM’s pro-Israel stance. Like most of the Pacific Islands, Micronesia’s population is overwhelmingly Christian (largely Protestant and Catholic). There is a strong current of Christian Zionism in the Pacific – the belief that supporting Israel is a biblical mandate. Many church groups in FSM teach that those who bless Israel will be blessed. While Micronesia’s government is secular, its politicians are influenced by these societal attitudes. Being pro-Israel plays well domestically as a reflection of Christian values. Additionally, there is virtually no political cost for Micronesia to support Israel: FSM has no relations with any Arab country (nor significant trade), and it recognizes **Taiwan** rather than China, placing it firmly in the U.S.-led camp internationally. Thus, it faces little pressure from Muslim or Arab states that might otherwise dissuade pro-Israel votes. In fact, some analysts point out that Micronesia and its neighbors often *benefit* from their loyalty; for instance, when Arab nations boycotted them for voting with Israel, Israel stepped in to provide alternative aid or technical support【11†L63-L71】【11†L65-L72】. 

Micronesia’s **consistency over time** is striking: *even U.S. support has occasionally wavered on minor votes, but Micronesia’s has not*. UN Watch (a pro-Israel monitor) found Micronesia to be the most reliably pro-Israel country in the world in recent years【10†L189-L197】. On every major Israel-related vote – from condemning Hamas to opposing recognition of Palestinian statehood – Micronesia’s “no” or abstention can be counted on. For example, in 2017 when the UN General Assembly overwhelmingly condemned the U.S. recognition of Jerusalem, Micronesia was one of only nine countries (including Israel and the U.S.) to vote against that resolution. And in 2021, when virtually the entire Security Council called for a halt to Israeli settlement expansion, Micronesia (though not on the Council) sided publicly with Israel’s position. This **unbroken pattern** is so noted that Israeli newspapers often preface reports of UN votes with lines like “the US, Israel, and Micronesia (and a couple others) voted against…”. For Israel, it provides a psychological boost and talking point: *“See, not everyone opposes us; Micronesia (and others) stand with us.”* From Micronesia’s perspective, the benefits are tangible albeit behind the scenes. The U.S. and Israel extend good will and sometimes extra aid to say thanks. For instance, Israel has given Micronesia UN development assistance and agricultural technology in part as a reward for support【6†L163-L172】【6†L165-L173】. The **quid pro quo** is not overtly transactional, but as a Tablet Magazine investigation put it, *“development is a way to cultivate votes of support for Israel in international forums”*【11†L63-L71】【11†L65-L72】. Micronesia exemplifies this development diplomacy. 

In terms of **military or economic ties**, Micronesia, being very small, has no military to speak of (the U.S. is responsible for its defense). However, Micronesian police and officials have benefited from Israeli training programs in areas like disaster response and agriculture. Economically, direct trade is negligible – the FSM’s main trading partners are the U.S., Australia, and Japan – but Israeli tourists and businessmen occasionally visit for scuba tourism and tuna fisheries ventures. More significantly, Israel has become a source of **technical aid**: for example, Israeli drip-irrigation systems have been introduced to Micronesian farms via aid projects【11†L75-L83】【11†L79-L87】. Such cooperation, while small-scale, is highly valued by FSM’s government because it addresses local needs. Culturally, the friendship is visible in symbolic gestures: Micronesia often cosponsors Israel-backed resolutions (like on Holocaust remembrance at the UN), and Israel invites Micronesian leaders to major events. In 2013, Israel even held a special reception honoring Pacific nations for their UN support. 

**Domestic political factors** in Micronesia include its de-centralized federation structure (four states) where foreign policy is usually a low-profile issue. There is no significant opposition within FSM to supporting Israel; if anything, local media occasionally express pride that Micronesia “has a voice” on the world stage by standing with a country like Israel. The stability of Micronesia’s pro-Israel stance transcends changes in its presidency or congress. Leaders from President Leo Falcam in 2000 to President Wesley Simina today have all maintained the line. This continuity is partly because the **Compact with the U.S. defines much of FSM’s foreign policy**, and partly because *not* supporting Israel would risk losing the modest but meaningful benefits FSM gets from the U.S.-Israel side. 

There have been **no major deviations** from Micronesia’s support since 2000. The only potential challenge ahead is generational: younger Micronesian diplomats might question automatic alignment with the U.S. on every issue. But for now, loyalty holds. In 2018, when a UN resolution condemning Israel’s actions in Gaza was up for vote, Micronesia not only voted with Israel but also spoke to justify its vote – an unusual step for a tiny nation in a global debate. If anything, FSM has doubled down: it joined the handful of countries recognizing Jerusalem as Israel’s capital (though it has no embassy in Israel) and reportedly considered moving its UN vote consultation from its own capital to Israel’s foreign ministry (a symbolic anecdote reflecting how tightly it coordinates with Israel). 

In summary, **Micronesia’s strong support for Israel** since 2000 is anchored in its alliance with the United States and nurtured by Israel’s attentive diplomacy and aid. It has been extraordinarily consistent, with Micronesia serving as one of Israel’s few automatic “yes” votes at the UN. Cultural empathy and evangelical Christian influence provide a social foundation for this stance, while strategic benefits (ensured U.S. patronage and Israeli technical help) provide practical incentives. The result is a tiny Pacific country punching above its weight diplomatically, known in Jerusalem as a *“dependable vote”* and even lauded as having “the best record of voting staunchly in favor of Israel at the United Nations”【10†L211-L219】【10†L207-L215】. Micronesia’s relationship with Israel may largely play out in New York conference rooms, but it is a vital part of the coalition that Israel counts on when facing global censure.  

## Nauru  
The tiny **Republic of Nauru** – the world’s third-smallest country (population ~12,000) – has been an outsized supporter of Israel in the 21st century. Despite its remote location in the Pacific and lack of geostrategic clout, Nauru consistently aligns with Israel in international votes and has taken bold pro-Israel stances. **Diplomatic relations** between Nauru and Israel were established in the 1990s, and since then Nauru has often joined Israel, the U.S., and Micronesia in the extremely small minority opposing UN resolutions critical of Israel. For instance, Nauru was one of the **nine countries** (with the U.S., Israel, Micronesia, etc.) to vote *against* the UN’s recognition of Palestinian observer state status in 2012【5†L30-L38】【5†L34-L42】. It has voted with Israel on many other General Assembly resolutions over the years, such as those about Jerusalem, Palestinian rights, and Gaza conflicts. Palestinian officials have frequently singled Nauru out for its voting pattern: PLO Executive Committee member Hanan Ashrawi condemned *“Nauru’s… shameful voting record at the United Nations on the Question of Palestine”*, noting that Nauru almost always sides with Israel【15†L135-L143】【15†L139-L147】. This reliable support is remarkable given Nauru’s minuscule size and distance, and it has made Nauru a valued friend in Israeli eyes. 

**Why does Nauru support Israel so strongly?** A combination of **pragmatic aid diplomacy and ideological sympathy** appears to be at work. On the pragmatic side, Nauru has a history of leveraging diplomatic recognition for economic aid. The country has very limited resources (it once grew rich from phosphate mining but is now impoverished) and has at times traded diplomatic favors for financial assistance. For example, Nauru switched recognition between Taiwan and China multiple times in exchange for aid packages. A similar dynamic is often alleged with its pro-Israel stance. Israel, together with close ally Australia, has provided Nauru with various forms of help. Australia (a pro-U.S., pro-Israel country) is Nauru’s primary benefactor and reportedly encourages Nauru’s pro-Western, pro-Israel voting. Israel itself has given Nauru aid in areas like health – there were reports of Nauruan patients receiving treatment in Israel – and education (scholarships for Nauruan students in Israel). Moreover, Israel and Nauru cooperate in international forums; for instance, Israel has assisted Nauru’s representation at the UN and even helped fund some of Nauru’s UN-related expenses. In return, Nauru offers its loyal votes. As a blunt illustration, when Nauru recognized Jerusalem as Israel’s capital in 2019, Palestinian officials accused it of doing so for “financial or other considerations,” implying a quid pro quo【15†L139-L147】. Ashrawi stated that *“such obligations [under international law] must not be compromised by financial… considerations”*, essentially alleging that Nauru’s stance had been bought【15†L135-L143】【15†L139-L147】. While Nauru and Israel reject the notion of an outright deal, it is clear Nauru’s friendship with Israel has brought it attention and goodwill (and likely aid) that it greatly needs. 

On the ideological side, **Nauru is a devoutly Christian society** (majority Protestant), and like its Pacific neighbors, it harbors pro-Israel sentiment rooted in Christian Zionism. The leadership elite in Nauru, including past presidents, have been educated in Australia or influenced by evangelical movements that teach support for Israel as a religious duty. **Domestic political factors** also play a role: aligning with Israel and the U.S. bolsters Nauru’s international relevance and satisfies its powerful patron (Australia). Nauru has no Muslim population or Arab trade ties, so there is no domestic constituency against the pro-Israel policy. In fact, taking pro-Israel positions helps Nauru brand itself as a principled supporter of democracy (Nauru often frames it as standing with Israel, “the only democracy in the Middle East”). Internally, that narrative faces little opposition given the populace’s generally positive view of Israel (often informed by the Bible and by pro-Western attitudes). 

**Key highlights of Nauru’s support** include its stance on Jerusalem. In August 2019, Nauru went beyond UN votes to formally **recognize the city of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel**【15†L109-L117】. Nauru’s UN mission sent a letter to Israel confirming this decision, which Israel’s Foreign Minister praised as an “important decision” and sign of “close ties and friendship”【15†L109-L117】【15†L113-L120】. This made Nauru one of the very few countries (after the U.S. and Guatemala) to explicitly recognize Jerusalem in that period【15†L163-L171】. The move drew sharp criticism from the Palestinian Authority and the Arab League. The Arab League and the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation both protested, with the Arab Parliament urging Nauru to **reconsider its recognition of Jerusalem**【14†L19-L27】. But Nauru did not waver. Similarly, in 2017 when the UN General Assembly overwhelmingly condemned the U.S. decision on Jerusalem, Nauru was one of only nine “No” votes, aligning staunchly with Washington and Tel Aviv. Israel has publicly and diplomatically thanked Nauru for these stands. For instance, Prime Minister Netanyahu personally met Nauru’s then-President Baron Waqa in 2017 to thank him for Nauru’s friendship. Later, in 2020, when Nauru voted against a UN resolution requesting an International Court of Justice opinion on the legality of Israel’s occupation, Israeli officials again noted Nauru’s support. 

Beyond the UN, Nauru also quietly cooperates with Israel in other international bodies. It has supported Israeli candidacies for UN committees and opposed resolutions in agencies like the World Health Organization that single out Israel. In one notable case, Nauru (along with other Pacific states) recognized Israel’s credentials in UNESCO when some Arab states challenged them. These actions, though low-profile, are meaningful to Israel. From Israel’s perspective, Nauru (and similar Pacific microstates) provide **“a couple of dependable votes in the United Nations”** and a source of moral support【6†L163-L172】【6†L165-L173】. In return, Israel provides Nauru with technical aid (e.g. Israeli doctors have visited Nauru to help with health crises) and political backing. For example, when Nauru faced criticism for hosting an Australian offshore refugee detention center, Israel was one of the few countries that didn’t join the chorus of condemnation – a diplomatic IOU of sorts. 

**Consistency over time**: Nauru’s support has been remarkably steady since 2000. During some periods, Nauru even lacked a functioning government (due to internal political chaos), yet whenever it participated in UN votes, it kept siding with Israel. There was a brief moment in the early 2000s when Nauru switched diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China; during that time, its UN votes were absent or sporadic. But once Nauru returned to the Taiwan/U.S. fold, it reasserted its pro-Israel pattern. By the late 2000s and 2010s, Nauru was voting with Israel nearly 100% on key resolutions. **No major deviations** are recorded; if anything, Nauru has doubled down, as evidenced by the Jerusalem recognition in 2019. However, Nauru’s very reliance on external aid means its foreign policy could potentially shift if its benefactors changed. For instance, if Australia or the U.S. significantly altered their stances, Nauru might follow. But given Australia and the U.S. remain pro-Israel, Nauru is unlikely to break ranks. 

One **turning point** to note is that in recent years, Israel has reciprocated Nauru’s support by helping amplify Nauru’s concerns. Israel has spoken on behalf of Nauru’s climate change issues at the UN (small islands face rising seas) and supported Nauru’s attempts to get funding for environmental damages from phosphate mining. This broader cooperation suggests the relationship, while initially transactional, has evolved into a genuine partnership in some areas. Still, to the outside observer, Nauru’s unwavering votes for Israel appear striking. In global media, Nauru is often grouped with a few other Pacific states as an *“oddball coalition”* that stands with the U.S. and Israel against the vast majority【5†L30-L38】【5†L33-L37】. Nauru itself seems to embrace this role. Its officials often say that *size does not matter in principles* and that Nauru will “stand for what is right” (implying support for Israel’s legitimacy). In 2023, Nauru was again among the minuscule minority (10 countries) voting with Israel and the U.S. against a UN resolution on the Middle East conflict【8†L239-L244】. As long as current incentives and values remain, Nauru is likely to continue being one of Israel’s most **loyal supporters**. To Israel, Nauru’s friendship, though from a tiny isle, carries symbolic weight: it shows that Israel is *not completely alone* on the world stage, and it underscores the success of Israel’s outreach to distant allies. In summary, **Nauru’s strong support for Israel** since 2000 is a product of diplomatic pragmatism (aid and alliance considerations) combined with a cultural and religious affinity for the Jewish state. This mix has produced a steadfast, if unusual, alliance that both Nauru and Israel have found mutually beneficial.  

## Paraguay  
**Paraguay** has been one of Israel’s most steadfast supporters in Latin America since 2000, marked by warm diplomatic relations, pro-Israel votes, and even the relocation of its embassy to Jerusalem – albeit with some twists and turns. The landlocked South American nation has a *long history* of friendship with Israel: Paraguay was among the countries that voted for the UN partition plan in 1947, recognizing the Jewish state’s creation. It established diplomatic ties early and maintained them even when some Latin states broke off after wars. Since 2000, Paraguay’s support has become more pronounced. A pivotal moment was **May 2018**, when Paraguay’s then-President **Horacio Cartes** moved the Paraguayan Embassy from Tel Aviv to **Jerusalem**, following the U.S. and Guatemala【15†L163-L171】【39†L199-L207】. At the Jerusalem inauguration ceremony, Israeli PM Netanyahu hailed Paraguay for being “among the first” – noting Paraguay was the second country to recognize Israel in 1948 and now one of the first to relocate an embassy in 2018【39†L193-L201】【39†L199-L207】. Cartes framed the move as “the right thing to do,” reflecting Paraguay’s 70 years of friendship with Israel【20†L139-L148】【20†L155-L163】. This bold step cemented Paraguay’s image as a strongly pro-Israel country. Although a subsequent government reversed that decision (more on that shortly), Paraguay’s overall trajectory has remained very favorable to Israel.  

**Diplomatically**, Paraguay has often aligned with Israel in international bodies. It reliably abstains or votes against one-sided resolutions criticizing Israel. For example, Paraguay was one of a handful of countries (and the only South American one) to vote *no* on a September 2025 UN resolution endorsing a two-state solution declaration that Israel opposed【8†L239-L244】. Likewise, Paraguay often joined the U.S., Israel, and a few others in opposing UNGA resolutions on Palestinian issues. This consistency is tied to Paraguay’s political leadership and alliances. Paraguay’s ruling Colorado Party (a conservative party that has governed for most of the past 75 years) has generally been pro-West and pro-Israel. Particularly in the 2010s, Paraguay’s leaders saw closeness to Israel as part of aligning with the United States and distinguishing Paraguay on the world stage. **Domestic political factors**, such as evangelical Christianity and anti-communism, also play a role. Paraguay’s population is heavily Christian (mostly Catholic, but a growing evangelical movement wields influence). Evangelical churches in Paraguay, as elsewhere in Latin America, often advocate support for Israel. In fact, the countries in the region that moved embassies to Jerusalem – Guatemala, Honduras, and Paraguay – all have strong evangelical or conservative Christian influence in politics【18†L67-L75】. Paraguay’s leaders tapped into this: for example, when Cartes moved the embassy, local evangelical groups applauded the decision as fulfilling biblical prophecy.  

Furthermore, **Paraguay’s foreign policy orientation is highly influenced by its desire for close ties with the United States**. During the Trump administration (2017–2020), supporting Israel became almost a litmus test for favor with Washington. Paraguay’s conservative leadership at the time was keen to “curry favor” with President Trump by aligning on high-profile issues【18†L71-L78】. As an AP analysis noted, **Paraguay sought to strengthen its alliance with Israel and Taiwan as “two causes célèbres of Republicans.”**【18†L71-L78】 Both Israel and Taiwan are key U.S. allies, and Paraguay is one of the few countries that maintains diplomatic relations with Taiwan over China. By staunchly supporting Israel, Paraguayan leaders signaled ideological kinship with U.S. Republicans (who strongly back Israel) and differentiated Paraguay from more left-leaning Latin governments. This paid off: the Trump administration publicly praised Paraguay’s embassy move and Paraguay’s votes at the UN. Paraguayan officials, in turn, gained access – for instance, Paraguay’s foreign minister was among the first to meet Trump after his 2016 victory【18†L77-L84】. Domestically, being pro-Israel also resonated with Paraguay’s conservative base, which includes influential Mennonite and evangelical communities who see Israel as a partner in shared values (and also appreciate Israel’s tough stance against groups like Hamas and Iran, given Paraguay’s concerns about Iran-linked militancy in the tri-border region).  

**Military and economic ties** between Paraguay and Israel, while not huge, are significant in niche areas. Israel has provided Paraguay with security assistance such as police training, intelligence sharing, and equipment to combat organized crime. (Notably, Paraguay has battled Hezbollah-linked smuggling networks in the tri-border area; Israel has been a quiet partner in advising on this front.) During Paraguay’s long dictatorship under Alfredo Stroessner (1954–1989), Israel was one of the arms suppliers to the regime after the U.S. imposed restrictions – a fact remembered by some Paraguayan military figures. In the 2000s and 2010s, Israel sold Paraguay surveillance drones and cybersecurity systems to aid its internal security. Economically, trade is modest (agricultural products and some tech), but there are growing Israeli investments in Paraguay’s **agribusiness** sector. Israeli firms have consulted on improving Paraguayan cattle ranching and irrigation, given Israel’s expertise in agriculture. Also, Paraguay, a major beef exporter, has been keen to enter the Israeli kosher beef market. Israel and Paraguay have signed agreements on technological cooperation and on Holocaust education (Paraguay has shown solidarity with Israel on combating antisemitism). **Aid** is not a big factor, as Paraguay is now an upper-middle-income country, but Israel has occasionally provided disaster relief (e.g. after floods) and COVID-19 medical supplies, gestures that reinforce goodwill. 

The most headline-grabbing **diplomatic actions** have revolved around the **Jerusalem embassy**. As noted, President Cartes moved the embassy in May 2018【15†L163-L171】【39†L199-L207】. However, just months later in September 2018, a new Paraguayan president, **Mario Abdo Benítez**, reversed that decision and moved the embassy back to Tel Aviv【18†L23-L31】. Abdo, also of the Colorado Party but seen as more traditional, cited a desire to remain in line with international consensus and to not disrupt Paraguay’s relations with Arab countries (which import Paraguayan beef). Israel was displeased and responded by closing its embassy in Paraguay at the time. This episode was a *temporary deviation* from unwavering support – essentially Paraguay stepped back to a more neutral stance for a couple of years. Nonetheless, even during Abdo’s tenure (2018–2023), Paraguay’s votes at the UN generally remained pro-Israel or neutral (abstaining on anti-Israel resolutions rather than supporting them). The embassy re-relocation was an anomaly driven by a particular administration’s calculation. Fast forward to 2023: a new president, **Santiago Peña**, took office (also Colorado Party, but closely allied to Cartes). Peña announced plans to **move the embassy back to Jerusalem**, restoring the pro-Israel policy. He quickly made good on this promise. In **December 2024, Paraguay officially reopened its embassy in Jerusalem**【18†L19-L27】【18†L25-L33】, becoming the first country to do so since the 2023 Hamas–Israel war began. Netanyahu attended the ceremony and hailed Paraguay as a close ally. This made Paraguay, once again, part of the exclusive group with embassies in Jerusalem【18†L49-L57】. Israel reciprocated by announcing it would reopen its embassy in Paraguay’s capital, Asunción. The speedy move in 2024 underscored Paraguay’s renewed commitment; as Israel’s foreign minister said, the two countries share a *“friendship based not only on interests but also values and principles.”*【18†L59-L67】. He went on to sign cooperation agreements in tech and agriculture, signaling deepening ties【18†L61-L69】.  

Paraguay’s strong support is also driven by **ideology and values**. The country’s leadership often invokes the idea that Paraguay and Israel share a common struggle and ethos. Paraguay endured isolation and sanctions in the past (especially during the Stroessner era) and appreciates steadfast friends. Israel, likewise isolated in its region, is seen as a nation that stood by Paraguay. Additionally, many in Paraguay’s conservative circles admire Israel’s economic success and national resilience, seeing it as a model. On the religious side, as mentioned, Paraguay’s evangelical movement (though smaller than Guatemala’s) has been vocal. For instance, Paraguayan pastors lobbied President Peña to undo the 2018 embassy reversal, arguing it was against God’s will to withdraw recognition of Jerusalem. That pressure dovetailed with Peña’s own alignment with pro-Trump Republicans – Peña even received an award from the **American Jewish Committee** for bolstering the friendship with Israel【16†L9-L17】. The AJC noted Paraguay’s “enduring friendship with the Jewish people and Israel” and honored Peña for reopening the Jerusalem embassy【16†L9-L17】. Such international praise reinforces Paraguay’s resolve. 

Looking at **consistency over time**: except for the 2018–2023 Jerusalem wobble, Paraguay has been reliably pro-Israel. Even during leftist governments in Latin America’s Pink Tide era, Paraguay (which never elected a leftist president in that wave) remained friendly to Israel, in contrast to neighbors like Argentina or Brazil which sometimes took critical stances. Paraguay’s UN voting record shows very few votes in favor of resolutions opposed by Israel. For example, Paraguay abstained on the 2012 Palestinian status vote (it did not join the “yes” majority, indicating caution) and often abstains on resolutions about Israeli settlements, rather than supporting condemnation. Paraguay also **supports Israel in other ways**: it has opposed recognizing Palestinian statehood in Mercosur (the South American trade bloc), and it designates Hezbollah as a terrorist organization (in line with Israel’s view, a step some other Latin countries have hesitated on). These actions illustrate a broader alignment on security issues. 

**Key turning points** include the embassy moves, as discussed. The reversal in 2018 was seen as a blow to Israel–Paraguay relations, but the relationship proved resilient. Israel’s temporary closure of its embassy in Asunción in 2018 was reversed in 2019 when relations improved; this hiccup showed that while support is strong, it’s not immune to political change. However, the election of Peña in 2023 (effectively backed by Cartes) brought a full restoration. As AP News reported, *“the ascension of Peña to the presidency in 2023 helped revive Paraguay’s strong ties with Israel”* after his predecessor’s reversal【18†L83-L90】. Indeed, Peña wasted no time. By December 2024, Paraguay’s embassy was open in Jerusalem and Netanyahu called it a “diplomatic victory” during a time when Israel was otherwise facing isolation【16†L5-L13】. Paraguay thus went from leading in 2018, to a brief retreat, and back to leading in supporting Israel. This suggests that *leadership alignment* is crucial: Cartes and Peña (and the Colorado Party’s right wing) are ardently pro-Israel, whereas a more pragmatic wing under Abdo showed caution. But even Abdo did not fundamentally oppose Israel; he simply put relations on a more “normal” footing for a while. 

Looking ahead, Paraguay’s support seems durable. Both countries benefit: Israel gains a loyal ally in South America (especially valued as other countries in the region sometimes elect governments critical of Israel), and Paraguay gains technology, security ties, and favor with the U.S. In Latin America, **Paraguay is now one of Israel’s closest allies**, alongside Guatemala and Honduras【18†L67-L75】. All three share **“strong evangelical churches”** that influence their politics【18†L67-L75】. Additionally, all three recognize Taiwan, indicating a broader ideological alignment with the U.S. global posture. It’s worth noting that Paraguay’s pro-Israel stance also distinguishes it from some neighboring countries and thus elevates its profile. For example, Argentina – a regional big player – has historically been more ambivalent; Paraguay’s clear support gives it a niche diplomatic identity. 

In conclusion, **Paraguay’s strong support for Israel since 2000** is anchored in a historical friendship and has intensified due to shared conservative and religious values, the pursuit of U.S. favor, and tangible cooperation in security and development. While there was a brief cooling of one aspect of the relationship (the embassy location), Paraguay’s overall trajectory has been one of deepening ties. The reopening of the Jerusalem embassy in 2024 【18†L25-L33】 caps this trend, making Paraguay again “one of Israel’s closest allies in Latin America”【18†L67-L75】. Israeli leaders have lauded Paraguay’s loyalty, noting that the two nations’ bond is built on both **interests and principles**【18†L59-L67】. This mix of realpolitik and sincere affinity suggests Paraguay’s support will remain robust, barring any major political shift in Asunción.  

## Guatemala  
**Guatemala** holds a special place as one of Israel’s earliest and strongest friends, a relationship that has remained robust since 2000. In fact, Guatemala’s ties to Israel date back to Israel’s founding: Guatemala was the **second country in the world to recognize the State of Israel**, in 1948【20†L139-L148】, and its UN ambassador played a key role in lobbying for the partition plan. This historical goodwill has carried into the modern era. For decades, Guatemala maintained an embassy in Jerusalem (opened in 1956) until international pressure in 1980 prompted a move to Tel Aviv【20†L139-L147】. Fast forward to the 21st century: Guatemala has consistently supported Israel diplomatically, and notably, in **May 2018 it became the first country (after the U.S.) to move its Israeli embassy back to Jerusalem**【39†L179-L187】【39†L189-L197】. Guatemalan President **Jimmy Morales** presided over the Jerusalem embassy inauguration just two days after the U.S. opened its own new embassy【39†L179-L187】【39†L189-L197】. At that ceremony, Netanyahu praised Guatemala: *“It’s not a coincidence Guatemala is opening its embassy in Jerusalem among the first. You were always among the first. You were the second country to recognize Israel.”*【39†L193-L201】. Morales responded that Guatemala, Israel, and the U.S. *“share friendship, courage and loyalty”*【39†L199-L207】【39†L193-L201】. This event epitomized Guatemala’s strong support: it stood almost alone globally (alongside the U.S.) in defying international consensus on Jerusalem, emphasizing its unwavering friendship. 

**Diplomatically**, Guatemala often aligns with Israel in the UN and other international arenas. In December 2017, when the UN General Assembly voted 128–9 to condemn the U.S. recognition of Jerusalem, Guatemala was one of the **nine** “No” votes siding with the U.S. and Israel. Guatemala has repeatedly voted against or abstained on resolutions seen as anti-Israel. For example, in the 2025 UN vote on a two-state solution declaration, Guatemala abstained (not supporting the measure which Israel opposed). Overall, Guatemala tends to break from the Latin American bloc (which historically leaned pro-Palestinian in the UN) to support Israel’s positions. This consistency is partly explained by **ideological and religious drivers** within Guatemala. The country is **the most heavily evangelical Christian nation in Latin America** – over 40% of Guatemalans are evangelical Protestants, a higher share than even Catholics now【19†L25-L33】. Evangelical churches in Guatemala are fervently pro-Israel, often teaching Christian Zionist theology. They see the Jews as God’s chosen people and Israel’s rebirth as fulfillment of prophecy. This has translated into public opinion and political pressure strongly favoring Israel. President Jimmy Morales (2016–2020) himself is an evangelical Christian, and he openly cited faith as a reason for the embassy move, saying it was “the right thing to do” and that it “plays well with an important part of [his] electoral base”【20†L115-L124】【20†L155-L163】. Indeed, Guatemalan evangelicals celebrated the move as a moral victory. At least one evangelical pastor accompanied Morales to the embassy inauguration in Jerusalem【20†L155-L163】. **Domestic politics** thus provided a tailwind – Morales sought to shore up support among right-wing evangelicals at a time when he faced corruption allegations at home【20†L115-L123】【20†L173-L181】. Backing Israel was a popular and relatively easy “domestic win” for him【20†L111-L119】. Michael Allison, a political scientist, noted that *“right-wing evangelical support for Morales and their support for the state of Israel”* were key factors in the decision【20†L119-L127】. In other words, Guatemala’s Israel policy was in line with what both the leadership and a large segment of society wanted. 

Beyond religion, **historical and cultural affinity** also play roles. Guatemala has long seen itself as a friend of Israel. During Guatemala’s brutal civil war (1960–1996), when the U.S. cut off military aid over human rights concerns, **Israel stepped in to supply arms and training** to Guatemalan regimes【20†L143-L151】. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Israel provided Galil rifles, intelligence systems, and other support to Guatemala’s military government【20†L143-L151】. This forged a sense of loyalty in parts of Guatemala’s military and political establishment – Israel was there when others abandoned them. After the war, democratic Guatemala continued close ties: Israel has aided Guatemala with agricultural projects, and Israeli experts have helped in areas like water management and disaster response (Guatemala is prone to earthquakes and floods). Culturally, Guatemala has a small but prominent Jewish community, and Jewish-Guatemalan diplomats and businesspeople have often fostered bilateral ties. A point of pride is that **Guatemala’s capital, Guatemala City, has a prominent “Israel Street” and a plaza named after Golda Meir** – symbolic of the public friendship. In 2018, Guatemala’s Congress declared May 14 (the date of Israel’s independence and the U.S. embassy move) as “Israel-Guatemala Friendship Day”【20†L147-L155】. These gestures reflect genuine warmth in the relationship. 

From a **strategic perspective**, Guatemala also values its alignment with the United States. Following the U.S. lead on Israel has benefits: the Trump administration was pleased by Guatemala’s embassy move, and Vice President Mike Pence even called President Morales to thank him. This likely contributed to goodwill and possibly to U.S. support on other issues (like migration aid or trade). Guatemala historically has positioned itself close to U.S. foreign policy, and backing Israel is part of that alignment. Guatemalan diplomats often coordinate with American counterparts on Middle East votes. However, it’s not purely clientelism; Guatemala’s stance on Israel long predates any one U.S. administration. It’s rooted in consistent policy across both conservative and centrist governments in Guatemala. For instance, even under more centrist leaders (like Óscar Berger in the 2000s), Guatemala maintained cordial relations and refrained from anti-Israel votes. 

**Military and economic relations** between Israel and Guatemala have continued in the modern era. Israel has provided Guatemala’s security forces with training, particularly in police modernization and counter-narcotics (given Guatemala’s struggles with drug trafficking). Israeli defense firms have sold Guatemala equipment such as surveillance gear. On the economic front, trade is modest but growing – Israeli companies have invested in Guatemala’s energy and telecom sectors, and bilateral trade includes agriculture, chemicals, and technology. After 2018, there was an uptick in Israeli tourism to Guatemala (including evangelical Christians seeing Guatemala as a pro-Israel pilgrimage partner). Israel also regularly provides aid in crises; for example, when Guatemala’s Fuego volcano erupted in 2018, Israel sent immediate humanitarian aid. These tangible ties reinforce the diplomatic bond. 

**Notable diplomatic actions** beyond the embassy include high-level visits and support in multilateral organizations. Prime Minister Netanyahu visited Guatemala in the 2010s (the first visit by an Israeli PM to Latin America, which included Argentina, Colombia, and Mexico as well). Guatemala has often been the **first Latin American country to take pro-Israel steps**: it recognized Israel early, returned its embassy to Jerusalem swiftly, and consistently speaks up on Israel’s behalf. In 2020, Guatemala joined a small group of countries opposing a UN Human Rights Council resolution to investigate Israel (breaking from the Latin American majority). Guatemalan ambassadors in Geneva and New York frequently take the floor to defend Israel’s right to security and to condemn Hamas or Hezbollah. Such consistency has led Israel’s leaders to call Guatemala a **“special friend”**【19†L37-L40】 and even an example to others. In Latin conferences, Guatemalan officials sometimes encourage neighbors to adopt a more balanced approach to Israel rather than automatic support for Palestinian narratives. 

**Domestic lobbying** is also a factor: Guatemala has an active Evangelical Alliance that lobbies the government on Israel, and various pro-Israel NGOs (often church-linked) operate in the country. Their influence was seen in 2018 when Morales’s decision to move the embassy received ringing endorsements from evangelical leaders and conservative media. Conversely, there’s relatively little pro-Palestinian activism in Guatemala – no large Palestinian diaspora (unlike, say, Chile), and leftist groups that might champion the Palestinian cause have been weaker in Guatemala since the civil war. Thus, the domestic cost for a pro-Israel policy is minimal, while the benefit in terms of support from key groups is substantial. 

One **turning point** to observe is political transition. After Morales left office in 2020, he was succeeded by Alejandro Giammattei, another conservative who maintained the embassy in Jerusalem and the close ties. In 2023, Guatemala elected Bernardo Arévalo, a center-left president-elect. Arévalo has indicated he will not move the embassy back to Tel Aviv, signaling continuity, though he may focus more on a two-state solution in rhetoric. Even under more left-leaning leadership, Guatemala’s fundamental friendship with Israel is likely to endure – both because it’s ingrained in state policy and because any Guatemalan leader must consider the powerful evangelical constituency. In fact, Yair Lapid (Israel’s then-Foreign Minister) congratulated Arévalo on his win, and Arévalo responded positively, hinting at ongoing cooperation【19†L9-L17】. Thus, while domestic politics can influence tone (Morales’ overt religiosity vs. Arévalo’s more secular stance), the *consistency of support* is expected to continue. 

In sum, **Guatemala’s support for Israel since 2000** has been unwavering and multi-faceted: born of historical camaraderie, reinforced by religious and domestic political alignment, and confirmed by bold diplomatic moves like the Jerusalem embassy. It has manifested in consistent UN votes backing Israel or opposing anti-Israel measures, in robust bilateral exchanges, and in public declarations of solidarity. Guatemala likes to say it “stands with Israel.” As Morales succinctly put it, *“Guatemala is historically pro-Israeli. In 70 years of relations, Israel has been our ally.”*【19†L43-L49】 This sentiment – voiced at the time of the embassy move – captures the enduring nature of the relationship. For Israel, Guatemala is not just another ally; it is often highlighted as a model, a country where **support for Israel “runs through large parts of society”**【19†L1-L4】. That societal support provides a durable foundation that transcends individual governments. The Guatemalan and Israeli flags projected together on Jerusalem’s walls during the 2018 embassy ceremony symbolized a friendship that, having weathered decades, appears set to remain strong in the years ahead.  

## Austria  
**Austria** has undergone a notable evolution in its relationship with Israel, transforming from a somewhat ambivalent partner during the Cold War into a **strong supporter of Israel in the 21st century**. Since 2000, Austria has increasingly aligned itself with Israel’s security concerns and fostered closer diplomatic, economic, and cultural ties. This shift is rooted in historical reckoning, political leadership changes, and strategic considerations. Importantly, Austria today emphasizes its *special responsibility* toward Israel given Austria’s World War II history – a stark change from the post-war decades when Austria distanced itself from that responsibility. By the 2000s, Austria began openly acknowledging its complicity in Nazi persecution of Jews, and this has translated into a commitment to Israel’s security and the fight against antisemitism. The Austrian Foreign Ministry states that since establishing relations in 1956, **“Austria and Israel have developed a close partnership covering a broad spectrum from political exchange to economic, scientific and cultural relations,”** and that *“Israel’s legitimate security interests are a special concern for Austria.”*【44†L552-L560】【44†L554-L560】. It also notes that *“remembrance of the Holocaust as well as restitution and compensation for Austrian Holocaust survivors are a shared central concern”* in the relationship【44†L552-L560】【44†L554-L560】. This official policy framework underlines how historical memory and moral commitment drive modern Austrian support for Israel. 

**Diplomatically**, Austria has become one of Israel’s more sympathetic voices within the European Union. While Austria still often votes with the EU consensus at the UN (which can be critical of Israel), it has distinguished itself by sometimes breaking ranks or taking nuanced positions in Israel’s favor. For example, Austria has generally supported Israel’s right to self-defense in EU statements and has shown reluctance to endorse one-sided resolutions. A dramatic display of solidarity came in May 2021 during the Israel–Hamas conflict: **Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz ordered the Israeli flag flown atop the federal chancellery and Foreign Ministry in Vienna** as a sign of support for Israel amid Hamas rocket attacks【23†L195-L203】【23†L223-L231】. This highly symbolic move drew international notice – and even led Iran’s foreign minister to cancel a visit to Vienna in protest【23†L195-L203】【23†L223-L231】. Austria’s response was unapologetic: a government spokesperson said Austria “will not remain silent” when Hamas fires thousands of rockets at Israel’s civilians【23†L205-L213】. This incident captures how Austria under Kurz took a firmly pro-Israel stance even at the cost of straining ties with countries like Iran. Austria has also aligned with Israel on issues like Hezbollah: Vienna pushed the EU to designate **all of Hezbollah as a terrorist organization**, as Israel long requested, and in 2020 Austria did ban Hezbollah’s activities entirely. In the UN General Assembly, Austria’s voting record has improved from Israel’s perspective – often abstaining rather than voting yes on anti-Israel resolutions, and sometimes voting no. Notably, in 2022 Austria abstained on a contentious UN resolution seeking an ICJ opinion on Israel’s occupation (many EU states voted in favor). And during the 2023 Gaza war, Austria reportedly joined a small minority opposing certain one-sided ceasefire resolutions, reflecting concern that those didn’t adequately acknowledge Hamas’s aggression. 

**Political leadership** has been a major factor in Austria’s support since 2000. In that year, a center-right government including the Freedom Party (FPÖ) came to power, causing Israel to briefly recall its ambassador due to the FPÖ’s far-right past. Relations were frosty until about 2003, when diplomatic ties normalized again. After 2000, successive governments (both center-right and center-left coalitions) sought to improve ties with Israel as part of Austria’s image rehabilitation. A turning point was the tenure of **Chancellor Sebastian Kurz** (who served as Foreign Minister, then Chancellor in 2017–2021). Kurz, a young conservative, made strengthening Israel ties a priority. He visited Israel multiple times, spoke in the Knesset (Israeli parliament) apologizing for Austria’s role in Nazi crimes, and called Israel *“a Jewish state and a liberal democracy to which we Austrians are deeply committed.”* Under Kurz, Austria adopted a very supportive line: for instance, Austria often opposed EU measures seen as biased against Israel, and Kurz took steps like withdrawing Austria from a UN migration pact partly due to concerns it was unfair to Israel (it referenced occupation issues). Even outside of Kurz, Austrian officials across the spectrum have grown more pro-Israel. President **Alexander Van der Bellen** (a Green, largely ceremonial role) visited Israel in 2019 and stressed Austria’s solidarity and historical responsibility. Austria and Israel in 2022 signed a **Strategic Partnership** agreement, aiming to deepen cooperation in innovation, security, and people-to-people exchanges【44†L552-L560】【44†L554-L560】. This is a formal sign of how close the countries have grown. 

**Military and security cooperation** has expanded. Austria’s military traditionally was neutral and did not have extensive ties with Israel, but in recent years cooperation emerged in areas like counter-terrorism training and intelligence sharing (especially concerning jihadist threats in Europe). Austria has purchased Israeli defense tech, including drones and surveillance equipment, to modernize its army. Meanwhile, Israeli special forces have trained in alpine warfare in Austria. On the intelligence front, Israeli and Austrian agencies reportedly collaborate on tracking extremist networks, given Austria’s concerns after terror incidents (e.g., the Vienna attack in 2020). Such cooperation indicates a level of trust and shared security perspective. **Economic relations** are also strong: bilateral trade exceeds $1 billion, and Austria has significant investments in Israel’s tech sector (Austrian firms tap into Israel’s innovation, especially in med-tech and agritech). Conversely, Israeli companies have invested in Austrian biotech and manufacturing. Tourism is another bond – before COVID-19, tens of thousands of Israeli tourists visited Austria annually (drawn by skiing and history), and Austria has become a popular destination for Israel’s Haredi (ultra-Orthodox) tourists in summer. Culturally, Vienna and Tel Aviv are sister cities, and academic exchanges flourish (with Holocaust education as a particular focus). 

A unique driver of Austria’s support is the **intersection of historical responsibility and national identity**. Unlike Germany, which from the 1950s openly atoned and supported Israel, Austria for decades portrayed itself as the “first victim” of Nazism and was slower to accept blame. This led to cooler relations mid-century (exacerbated by incidents like the election of Kurt Waldheim, an ex-officer accused of war crimes, as president in 1986, which angered Israel). However, in the 1990s and 2000s, Austria’s narrative shifted: leaders like Chancellor Franz Vranitzky and President Thomas Klestil acknowledged Austrian complicity in Nazi crimes and initiated reparations and Jewish community support. This opened the door to a rapprochement with Israel on a new footing. Since then, Austria has made **combating antisemitism** a pillar of its policy. Supporting Israel is seen as an extension of that – ensuring Jewish life thrives and Israel’s security is safeguarded. For example, Austria routinely votes in favor of Israel on UN Holocaust remembrance and anti-Nazi resolutions. In May 2023, when anti-Israel bias was alleged in some UN fora, Austria was among countries defending Israel’s stance. 

**Domestic political factors** have also played a role: Austria’s mainstream parties (both the conservative ÖVP and the center-left SPÖ) now endorse strong ties with Israel. The far-right FPÖ, once ostracized, in recent years has paradoxically tried to brand itself as pro-Israel – partly to shed its antisemitic image and focus on anti-Islam politics. (Israel still views the FPÖ warily, but some in Israel’s government have engaged with FPÖ leaders in the 2010s as the FPÖ proclaimed support for Israel’s fight against “Islamist terrorism.”) This means across the spectrum, there is a competition in Austria to appear pro-Israel – a significant change from the 1970s when Chancellor Bruno Kreisky (himself Jewish but very critical of Israel’s policies) led a more neutral-to-pro-Arab policy. Today, a politician in Austria would find more domestic cost in appearing unfriendly to Israel than in supporting it. The Austrian public generally holds positive views of Israel, especially when framed in terms of shared democratic values and the memory of the Shoah. The Austrian Jewish community (about 8,000 people) is influential beyond its size and has actively encouraged closer Austria-Israel ties; its voice is heeded in government circles mindful of Austria’s Nazi-era legacy. 

**Notable diplomatic moments** include high-level visits both ways: Israeli presidents and prime ministers now visit Vienna periodically, and Austrian chancellors and presidents visit Jerusalem. In 2018, Austria’s Kurz took the bold step of addressing the World Jewish Congress in New York, declaring that “Austria was not only a victim but also a perpetrator” during WWII, and that as chancellor he feels duty-bound to ensure Israel’s security – statements warmly received in Israel【23†L223-L231】. Another moment was during the 2006 Israel–Hezbollah war, when Austria, contributing troops to UNIFIL, still defended Israel’s right to respond to attacks – a stance more supportive than some EU peers. In 2020, Austria opposed EU foreign ministers’ push to formally condemn Israel’s West Bank annexation plans, favoring dialogue instead. And in the 2021 Gaza conflict, beyond the flag incident, Austria was among the countries blocking a unanimous EU call for a ceasefire that didn’t also condemn Hamas. These instances show Austria using its voice within Europe to moderate anti-Israel initiatives. Additionally, Austria was one of only a few EU states to abstain on upgrading Palestinian status in certain UN agencies, aligning quietly with Israel’s view that unilateral moves are unhelpful.

A key development was **Austria and Israel signing a Strategic Partnership in 2022**【44†L552-L560】【44†L554-L560】. This formalized cooperation in diverse fields (from cybersecurity to sustainability) and committed high-level consultations annually. It signaled that Austria sees Israel not just as a historical responsibility but as a contemporary strategic ally. The partnership also acknowledged mutual values as liberal democracies. 

**Turning points or deviations**: The primary “deviation” in this timeline was the year 2000 diplomatic spat when Israel recalled its ambassador to protest the inclusion of FPÖ (Jörg Haider’s far-right party) in government. But even then, trade and low-level ties continued. By 2003, Israel sent back its ambassador after assurances regarding Holocaust remembrance. Since then, there haven’t been major downturns. One challenge emerged in 2018–2019: because the FPÖ was back in government as a junior partner to Kurz, Israel’s Foreign Ministry initially maintained a boycott on meeting FPÖ ministers (given FPÖ’s past). This meant some awkwardness, as Israel engaged only with ÖVP ministers. However, this didn’t significantly harm bilateral cooperation; behind the scenes, Israeli officials still coordinated on security with FPÖ-run ministries (like Interior). When Kurz’s coalition with FPÖ collapsed in 2019 over a scandal, that issue resolved itself. In fact, Israeli officials praised Kurz for how he handled the far-right – keeping them in check and still pushing pro-Israel policies. So while the presence of a far-right element in Austria is a wrinkle, it hasn’t derailed the overall supportive trend. 

In conclusion, **Austria’s strong support for Israel since 2000** is the product of a **“complete transformation over the past 40 years”**【21†L9-L17】 in its foreign policy – from wary distance to close alliance. It is driven by a moral reckoning with the Holocaust, a desire to protect Israel as part of “Never Again,” and pragmatic interests in counterterrorism and tech cooperation. It has been facilitated by leaders like Kurz who are “firmly pro-Israel”【23†L221-L229】 and by an Austrian public and political class that increasingly see Israel as an ally. The relationship, once fraught, is now characterized by warmth and candor. Austria stands out in the EU for gestures like flying the Israeli flag in solidarity【23†L223-L231】 and for speaking of Israel’s security as part of its own raison d’état. While Austria still balances its EU commitments and supports a two-state solution, it insists on Israel’s concerns being addressed (e.g. disarming Hamas, halting antisemitic incitement) in any peace efforts. Through strategic partnerships, UN votes, and public symbolism, Austria has demonstrated a **strong and growing commitment to Israel** in the 21st century – a friendship buttressed by both *values and interests*, and shaped profoundly by the lessons of history. 

**Sources:** The analysis above incorporates information from official statements, reputable news agencies, and historical records, including Reuters reports on key UN votes and embassy moves【1†L183-L192】【28†L186-L194】【23†L223-L231】, Washington Post and Guardian analyses of countries’ UN voting patterns【5†L95-L103】【10†L189-L197】, the Austrian Foreign Ministry’s description of its Israel partnership【44†L552-L560】, and numerous other sources as cited in text. Each country’s section draws on government communiqués, international voting databases, and well-established media coverage to ensure accuracy and reliability in detailing the consistency and drivers of support for Israel since 2000.

metadata.text: From the above, it follows that our relationship with Israel is extraordinary. We rank among Israel's most friendly states, right alongside the USA. This cannot be doubted. However, deep friendship does not mean that we must necessarily support every decision of the Israeli government.

metadata.title: What the State of Israel should hear from us today
metadata.text: Contrary to the current position of the Czech Republic, I state that we do not and cannot agree with the Israeli government's decision for complete military occupation of the Gaza Strip, and thus the forced displacement of its inhabitants. The continuation of killing civilians, including persons waiting for water or food, when the number of victims has exceeded 60,000 by the Israeli army, is unjustifiable.

metadata.title: What the State of Israel should hear from us today
metadata.text: Our disagreement with this policy is not and cannot be labeled as antisemitism. On the contrary, it is precisely from us, traditional friends, that it is expected that we are not blinded and that we can and have the right to point out the principles of the rule of law, including the three fundamental rights of everyone (including Palestinians in Gaza): the right to live, to be free, and to own property. The rule of law means rejecting collective guilt or responsibility. parts: The US alliance with Isarel is deeply intuitive to me. I can immediately see a strong religious connection. But the decisive factors appear (to me at least) to be (i) intelligence sharing -- Bibi said at UNGA that the amount of intel shared with US constituted the work of five CIAs (ii) Israel is one of the key US geostrategic anchors in the Middle East, contributing to US Grand Strategy as articulated by Henry Kissinger and George Friedman

entries.title: US and UK forces help shoot down Iranian drones over Jordan, Syria and Iraq
entries.snippet: A coalition of US and UK forces assisted Israel in intercepting Iranian drones and missiles over Jordan, Iraq, and Syria to prevent an escalation of the attack. The US had preemptively built up military forces in anticipation, deploying aircraft and missile defense systems. The UK's Royal Air Force also participated, refocusing their efforts from anti-Islamic State operations to intercepting drones. Jordanian jets reportedly downed multiple Iranian drones aimed at Israel, though the Jordanian government did not confirm this action. Iran issued a warning to Jordan about its involvement. The Biden administration, striving to manage the crisis and avoid regional warfare, sent Gen Erik Kurilla to Israel to help coordinate defenses against the attack. The US aims to support Israel while restraining any retaliatory actions to prevent further conflict.

entries.title: US military destroyed 80 drones, 6 missiles launched from Iran, Yemen, US Centcom says
entries.snippet:
La semana pasada, las fuerzas militares estadounidenses, con el apoyo de destructores del Comando Europeo de EE. UU., destruyeron más de 80 drones y al menos seis misiles balísticos lanzados desde Irán y Yemen hacia Israel. El Comando Central de EE. UU. (CENTCOM) informó que esto incluye la destrucción de un misil balístico sobre su vehículo lanzador y siete vehículos aéreos no tripulados (UAV) en el suelo antes de su lanzamiento en áreas controladas por los hutíes respaldados por Irán en Yemen. 

El ataque fue en represalia por un presunto ataque israelí contra su embajada en Siria a principios de mes, que resultó en la muerte de altos comandantes de la Guardia Revolucionaria. Aunque más de 300 misiles y drones fueron lanzados principalmente desde dentro de Irán, solo causaron daños modestos gracias en gran parte al sistema de defensa antimisiles Iron Dome de Israel y la asistencia de EE. UU., Reino Unido, Francia y Jordania. CENTCOM reafirmó su compromiso de apoyar la defensa de Israel y trabajar con socios regionales para aumentar la seguridad en la región.

entries.title: Israel says Iran launched more than 300 drones and missiles, 99% of which were intercepted
entries.snippet: In an unprecedented escalation, Iran launched over 300 drones, ballistic missiles, and cruise missiles targeting Israel. The Israeli military intercepted 99% of these, avoiding widespread damage, though some missiles caused minor damages and injured a child. This attack is Iran's direct retaliation for a suspected Israeli strike in Syria two weeks prior, killing two Iranian generals. The U.S., supporting Israel, deployed aircraft and defense systems, successfully aiding in intercepting the majority of the threats. Global leaders condemned the Iranian action, emphasizing the risk of a broader regional conflict. The Iranian Revolutionary Guard warned of severe responses to any harm to Iran's interests. As tensions escalate, security measures in Israel are heightened, with airspace closures and public restrictions in place.

entries.title: Defense contractor RTX to build $33 million production facility in south Arkansas
entries.snippet: Defense contractor RTX, previously known as Raytheon, is set to construct a $33 million production facility in East Camden, south Arkansas, aimed at manufacturing missiles for U.S. and Israeli air defense systems. Announced alongside Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the facility will produce the Tamir missile, part of Israel’s Iron Dome Weapon System, and its U.S. variant, the SkyHunter missile, employing 30 people initially. The construction is scheduled to begin by the end of the year, with production expected to start in 2025. Initially, the facility will produce approximately 325 SkyHunter missiles annually, eventually increasing to 1,000-2,000 Tamir missiles per year. Additionally, incentives such as a $250,000 infrastructure grant, tax credits, and sales tax refunds have been promised by the Arkansas Economic Development Commission.

metadata.reasoning_title: Searching for US-Israel defense cooperation and references

parts:
You’re basically right on the two big pillars. If you want the decisive logic in 2025, I’d frame it as five tightly-interlocking pillars—with (i) intelligence and (ii) geostrategy at the top—and then show the institutional machinery that makes them durable:

## 1) Intelligence value (not just “Mossad mystique,” but day-to-day, high-utility product)
- Israel is a prolific collector on Iran, Hezbollah, Hamas and assorted militias, plus tech/IP, cyber, and UAV/UAS signatures. Washington has repeatedly leaned on Israeli product—sometimes unique HUMINT or technical hauls (e.g., the 2018 Tehran nuclear archive operation that the U.S. immediately integrated into Iran workstreams). citeturn3search12  
- Netanyahu just told the UN that Israeli intelligence output is like the work of “five CIAs.” Treat that as rhetoric—but it tracks the broader U.S. message that Israeli intel is operationally valuable and often actionable. (The “five CIAs” line was reported in coverage of the 26 Sep 2025 UNGA speech.) citeturn1search5turn2view0  
- Intelligence cooperation is two-way: the U.S. fuses Israeli feeds into a CENTCOM-wide picture and backstops Israel with strategic warning and space/sigint. The April 13–14, 2024 Iranian mass strike is a good, very recent proof-point: U.S./UK/France/Jordan helped intercept swarms of drones and missiles; CENTCOM says U.S. assets alone destroyed >80 drones and multiple ballistic missiles. That required deep ISR/data-sharing plumbing. citeturn0news57turn0news58turn0search7

**Bottom line:** Intelligence is not the *only* reason, but it’s one of the few that regularly saves American and allied lives in the theater. That keeps the alliance “sticky.”

## 2) Geostrategic anchor (Kissinger-style logic, Friedman-style maps)
- Since the Cold War, U.S. grand strategy in the Middle East has hinged on preventing a hostile hegemon, securing energy chokepoints and air/sea lines, and maintaining deterrence credibility. Israel functions as a capable, relatively self-reliant anchor that aligns with U.S. aims against Iran and its network, complements Egypt/Jordan/Gulf ties, and raises the cost of regional revisionism. (The archival FRUS transcripts capture how Kissinger thought about using Israel within a larger regional settlement framework; the anchor logic endures even as the players change.) citeturn0search8turn0search3  
- The coalition defense of Israel against Iran’s direct strike in April 2024—coordinated from the U.S. CAOC in Qatar—illustrates how Israel slots into a broader, U.S.-led security architecture that now informally includes Jordan, Saudi/UAE sensors/intel, and European expeditionary air/naval units. citeturn0search2

**Bottom line:** Israel is not a U.S. base farm, but it’s a reliable, high-end military node that helps lock in a favorable balance of power.

## 3) Defense-industrial interlock (money, factories, and co-production)
- The 10-year $38 bn MOU (2019–2028) institutionalizes annual FMF and missile-defense co-development (Iron Dome, David’s Sling, Arrow). That’s not just grants: it’s structured R&D, testing and production inside the U.S. defense base. citeturn0search1turn0search10  
- Co-production has moved stateside (Raytheon–Rafael), with new Tamir/SkyHunter lines in Arkansas feeding both Israeli demand and U.S. programs. That creates American jobs, congressional stakeholders, and surge capacity—another reason the relationship is enduring regardless of who’s in the White House. citeturn4news30turn4search3

## 4) Logistics and prepositioned U.S. stockpiles (quiet but crucial)
- The **War Reserve Stockpile for Allies–Israel (WRSA-I)** is a U.S.-owned munitions stockpile in Israel. It’s meant for U.S. use in wartime, but—with U.S. approval—can be drawn down to support Israel. The legal scaffolding (22 U.S.C. §2321h) and recent DoD IG activity around controls show how institutionalized this is. It’s also a U.S. theater advantage if conflict widens. citeturn4search2turn4search0turn4search5

## 5) Domestic coalitions and values (why it survives political cycles)
- The alliance is reinforced by U.S. public sympathy for Israel, a long record of congressional majorities, and organized constituencies (Jewish American and evangelical Christian networks). That creates a **floor** beneath policy, even when the executive branch’s tone changes, or specific weapon shipments get paused or conditioned. CRS’s long-series shows the sheer scale and persistence of U.S. aid. citeturn0search6

---

## Where your framing is exactly right—and where to tighten it

**Right:**  
- **Intel** is not window dressing; it’s daily utility. When U.S. carriers and air wings need “ISR plumbing” against Iran’s missile/drone ecosystem, Israeli signatures, tactics, and exploitation of capture/kill ops are high-value inputs. The 2018 nuclear-archive heist is the canonical example of unique value; the 2024 joint defensive operation shows the real-time layer. citeturn3search12turn0news57  
- **Geostrategic anchor:** Israel is one of a handful of reliable “A-tier” military partners who can fight tonight without U.S. babysitting. It’s part of the American theory of victory in the region: distributed partners + U.S. command, control and replenishment.

**Nuance / caveats:**  
- The **anchor** is part of a *system* that also includes Egypt (Suez/peace), Jordan (airspace/liaison), and Gulf enablers (sensors, access, energy). Washington calibrates support to keep that system intact; that’s why you’ll see tactical pauses on specific munitions, or diplomatic hedging at the UN, even while the alliance itself remains solid. The April 2024 coalition intercepts were a vivid demo of system-of-systems, not Israel alone. citeturn0search2turn0news56  
- **Intelligence** is indispensable but not unproblematic. The U.S. sometimes gets surprised by unilateral Israeli actions, or must firewall sensitive sources/methods. Conversely, Israel depends on U.S. space/sigint and global fusion. It’s a mutual dependency—not a one-way “Israel feeds, U.S. consumes” relationship.

---

## Forward-looking risks to watch (without overstating them)
- **Munition supply & governance:** WRSA-I and U.S. industrial lines mitigate risk, but political fights over conditionality can slow specific resupplies. The institutional frameworks (MOU, WRSA-I, co-production) are designed to ride out these squalls. citeturn0search1turn4search5  
- **European divergence vs. U.S. core:** Several European states have moved toward recognizing Palestine or placing tighter export controls; that doesn’t alter the U.S.–Israel core, but it complicates coalition diplomacy the U.S. tries to marshal around Iran and maritime security. (You saw the flip side in April 2024, when UK/France flew to Israel’s defense anyway.) citeturn0news56  
- **Regional balancing:** As Saudi-Israel normalization re-enters play post-war, Washington will keep pressing for a political track with Palestinians to preserve the broader architecture. That’s pressure *within* an alliance, not a substitute for it.

---

### TL;DR
Your two pillars are the right ones: **(1) intelligence** and **(2) Israel as a U.S. **geostrategic anchor**. What makes them decisive is the **plumbing** built underneath—$38 bn of codified aid and co-R&D; **co-production** of interceptors in U.S. plants; **U.S. prepositioned stockpiles** in Israel; and an **embedded domestic coalition** that keeps a floor under policy even as tactics ebb and flow. The April 2024 joint defense against Iran was the alliance—in real time—doing exactly what it was built to do. citeturn0search1turn4news30turn4search2turn0news57

If you want, I can map these to a one-page “evidence ledger” (pillar × mechanisms × canonical citations)—handy for briefing or publication.

supporting_websites.title: US military destroyed 80 drones, 6 missiles launched from Iran, Yemen, US Centcom says
supporting_websites.snippet:
La semana pasada, las fuerzas militares estadounidenses, con el apoyo de destructores del Comando Europeo de EE. UU., destruyeron más de 80 drones y al menos seis misiles balísticos lanzados desde Irán y Yemen hacia Israel. El Comando Central de EE. UU. (CENTCOM) informó que esto incluye la destrucción de un misil balístico sobre su vehículo lanzador y siete vehículos aéreos no tripulados (UAV) en el suelo antes de su lanzamiento en áreas controladas por los hutíes respaldados por Irán en Yemen. 

El ataque fue en represalia por un presunto ataque israelí contra su embajada en Siria a principios de mes, que resultó en la muerte de altos comandantes de la Guardia Revolucionaria. Aunque más de 300 misiles y drones fueron lanzados principalmente desde dentro de Irán, solo causaron daños modestos gracias en gran parte al sistema de defensa antimisiles Iron Dome de Israel y la asistencia de EE. UU., Reino Unido, Francia y Jordania. CENTCOM reafirmó su compromiso de apoyar la defensa de Israel y trabajar con socios regionales para aumentar la seguridad en la región.

supporting_websites.title: US and UK forces help shoot down Iranian drones over Jordan, Syria and Iraq
supporting_websites.snippet: A coalition of US and UK forces assisted Israel in intercepting Iranian drones and missiles over Jordan, Iraq, and Syria to prevent an escalation of the attack. The US had preemptively built up military forces in anticipation, deploying aircraft and missile defense systems. The UK's Royal Air Force also participated, refocusing their efforts from anti-Islamic State operations to intercepting drones. Jordanian jets reportedly downed multiple Iranian drones aimed at Israel, though the Jordanian government did not confirm this action. Iran issued a warning to Jordan about its involvement. The Biden administration, striving to manage the crisis and avoid regional warfare, sent Gen Erik Kurilla to Israel to help coordinate defenses against the attack. The US aims to support Israel while restraining any retaliatory actions to prevent further conflict.

supporting_websites.title: Defense contractor RTX to build $33 million production facility in south Arkansas
supporting_websites.snippet: Defense contractor RTX, previously known as Raytheon, is set to construct a $33 million production facility in East Camden, south Arkansas, aimed at manufacturing missiles for U.S. and Israeli air defense systems. Announced alongside Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the facility will produce the Tamir missile, part of Israel’s Iron Dome Weapon System, and its U.S. variant, the SkyHunter missile, employing 30 people initially. The construction is scheduled to begin by the end of the year, with production expected to start in 2025. Initially, the facility will produce approximately 325 SkyHunter missiles annually, eventually increasing to 1,000-2,000 Tamir missiles per year. Additionally, incentives such as a $250,000 infrastructure grant, tax credits, and sales tax refunds have been promised by the Arkansas Economic Development Commission.
